questions.text: A 48-hour-old newborn girl develops bilious emesis and refuses to breastfeed. She was born via C-section at 38 weeks due to nonreassuring fetal heart rates to a primigravid mother who received inconsistent prenatal care. Prior to the vomiting, the neonate was voiding urine normally but has not yet passed her first stool. The patient’s mother states she has no significant medical history but that her father died from pneumonia at the age of 44. The patient’s vitals are stable and within normal limits. Examination shows abdominal distension with palpable intestinal loops. Rectal examination shows normal tone and no stool in the rectal vault. X-ray of the abdomen shows air-fluid levels and small bowel dilation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this newborn’s condition?

choices.text: Intestinal obstruction caused by viscid meconium
Decreased intestinal motility due to low thyroxine levels

questions.solution:
Meconium ileus is often the first manifestation of cystic fibrosis (CF) and occurs in approximately 20% of patients diagnosed with CF. This neonate received inconsistent prenatal care; if a prenatal ultrasound had been performed, meconium ileus would likely have been detected by the presence of hyperechoic bowel or peritoneal calcifications. The mother is a carrier of CF, which can be deduced from her father dying of respiratory complications at a young age, likely due to CF.  

CF is characterized by an absent or abnormal transmembrane ion channel that regulates chloride transport. This abnormality interferes with bicarbonate, sodium, and water secretion, ultimately resulting in inadequate luminal hydration. The inspissated luminal contents can result in a meconium ileus, which obstructs normal small bowel passage. Neonates typically present with failure to pass his/her first stool (meconium), abdominal distension, and occasionally bilious vomiting. Complications include intestinal perforation, which would present with signs of sepsis (e.g., tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension).  



Option Analysis

❌ Abnormal neural crest cell migration:
Incorrect: Newborns with Hirschsprung’s disease (HD) also typically present with signs of intestinal obstruction in the neonatal period. However, rectal examination of HD patients would show increased rectal tone, as well as the “squirt sign,” in which there is forceful expulsion of stool during digital rectal palpation. Additionally, abdominal x-ray would show a dilation of the colon, not the small bowel.
✅ Intestinal obstruction caused by viscid meconium  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Failure to recanalize the duodenum:
Incorrect: Duodenal atresia is characterized by bilious vomiting several hours to days after birth and may also present with a distended abdomen; however, abdominal x-ray would demonstrate the “double bubble” sign, which is seen as two bubbles – one in the stomach and one in the duodenum. 
❌ Hypertrophy of the pyloric sphincter:
Incorrect: Hypertrophy of the pyloric sphincter is seen in pyloric stenosis, which most commonly presents in boys. Patients typically present with projectile, nonbilious vomiting immediately after feeding and abdominal palpation would reveal an olive-shaped pylorus. Failure to pass meconium is not a typical presentation, as it takes several weeks for the pylorus to hypertrophy. 
❌ Decreased intestinal motility due to low thyroxine levels :
Incorrect: Congenital hypothyroidism in neonates does not manifest until after several weeks to months of life; this is because the placenta supplies the fetus with maternal thyroid hormone. This patient’s intestinal obstruction with bilious vomiting, therefore, is unlikely to be caused by hypothyroidism.

questions.text: An infant boy is born at 40 weeks gestation to a 26-year-old woman. The delivery was uncomplicated, and Apgar scores were 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The patient was conceived via in vitro fertilization; the prenatal course was uncomplicated. The newborn’s father underwent microsurgical epididymal sperm aspiration due to a lack of sperm in his ejaculate. The father has a history of recurrent infections and chronic diarrhea. The patient’s vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the neonate is normal. A heel-prick test detects elevated serum levels of immunoreactive trypsinogen. Which of the following tests would most likely confirm the diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Genetic tests for dynein arm mutation
Measurement of T-cells by flow cytometry

questions.solution:
Cystic fibrosis (CF) is the most common autosomal recessive disorder in patients of Northern European descent. This patient’s father likely has CF, as indicated by the infertility (spermatogenesis is unaffected, but the congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens in CF patients impairs proper flow of sperm into the ejaculate), recurrent infections, and chronic diarrhea. 

Mandatory newborn screening involves a heel-prick test that detects immunoreactive trypsinogen (IRT). IRT is a precursor to trypsin that is normally found in the pancreas. In infants with CF, pancreatic ducts are partially blocked, leading to abnormal enzyme drainage with a resultant elevation of IRT. Heterozygous carriers of cystic fibrosis can also have a raised IRT, and therefore, it is not diagnostic. Diagnosis is confirmed with quantitative pilocarpine iontophoresis, better known as the sweat test. After chemical stimulation of the sweats glands with pilocarpine, the amount of chloride in the sweat is measured. Sweat chloride levels > 60 mmol/L are consistent with the diagnosis of CF.  



Option Analysis

✅ Quantitative pilocarpine iontophoresis :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Genetic tests for dynein arm mutation:
Incorrect: Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is a genetic condition that is characterized by absent or dysmotile cilia caused by a defect in the dynein arm of microtubules. Although patients with PCD may present with symptoms similar to those of CF, such as recurrent sinusitis, infertility, and a chronic cough, this neonate’s initial positive heel-prick test for immunoreactive trypsinogen is not suggestive of PCD.
❌ Hemoglobin electrophoresis:
Incorrect: Hemoglobin electrophoresis is used in newborns to confirm the diagnosis of various hemoglobinopathies, such as sickle cell disease or thalassemias. This patient’s positive heel-prick test for immunoreactive trypsinogen is not suggestive of hemoglobin disorders. 
❌ Serum alpha-1 antitrypsin levels :
Incorrect: Alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency is a disorder characterized by impaired synthesis and secretion of AAT. Patients present with pulmonary manifestations (e.g. emphysema), as well as liver involvement (e.g., hepatitis, cirrhosis). This patient’s positive heel-prick test for immunoreactive trypsinogen, however, is not suggestive of AAT deficiency. 
❌ Measurement of T-cells by flow cytometry:
Incorrect: Flow cytometry of T-cells is the confirmatory test for various immunodeficiencies. This patient’s father had recurrent infections and chronic diarrhea, which can also be seen in immunodeficiencies such as SCID. However, this patient’s positive heel-prick test for immunoreactive trypsinogen is suggestive of a different condition.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old child with intellectual disability is brought to the clinic by his parents due to progressive growth of facial lesions. His parents first noted it a few months ago and tried several over-the-counter creams with minimal improvement. Medical history is notable for seizures, hyperactivity, and mild cognitive dysfunction. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals the facial lesions shown below:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia    

Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be found on further examination of this patient?

choices.text: Elevated skin lesions with rough texture

questions.solution:
The presentation of intellectual disability, seizures, and angiofibromas (seen in the picture) is consistent with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC). Shagreen patches are rough, leathery, hamartomas of connective tissue which are often found on the lower back of patients with TSC.  

TSC is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder caused by a mutation in the tumor suppressor gene TSC1 on chromosome 9 or TSC2 on chromosome 16. The condition is characterized by hamartomas in CNS and skin, angiofibromas, shagreen patches (leathery skin), hypomelanotic macules ("ash leaf spots"), cardiac rhabdomyoma, renal angiomyolipoma, intellectual disability and behavioral problems. Patients are also at increased risk for various types of malignancy (e.g. subependymal giant cell tumors). The expression of the disease varies substantially, a phenomenon known as variable expressivity. The diagnosis of TSC can be made clinically or through genetic testing.  





Option Analysis

❌ Vascular lesions in the retina:
Incorrect: This finding would be consistent with the hemangioblastomas seen in von Hippel-Lindau (VHL)  disease. Other VHL manifestations include hemangioblastomas in the cerebellum, bilateral renal cell carcinomas, and pheochromocytomas.    
❌ Bilateral opacification of the lens:
Incorrect: Juvenile cataract is characteristic of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2). Other NF2 manifestations include vestibular schwannomas, meningiomas, and ependymomas.    
✅ Elevated skin lesions with rough texture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Triphalangeal thumb  :
Incorrect: Triphalangeal thumbs are associated with Diamond-Blackfan anemia (DBA), a congenital form of pure red cell aplasia. Other DBA findings include short stature and craniofacial abnormalities.    
❌ Patches of cutaneous hyperpigmentation:
Incorrect: Cutaneous hyperpigmentation, or café-au-lait spots, can be seen in patients with neurofibromatosis. This patient is presenting with tuberous sclerosis, which instead presents with patches of cutaneous hypopigmentation, also known as ash leaf spots.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man comes to the clinic due to difficulty seeing in the right eye. He describes progressive blurry vision that started about a month ago. The patient denies any trauma and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. The patient’s father passed away from a kidney condition, but he does not recall the exact details. A retinal angiogram is obtained, and the results are shown below:  

 

 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

The doctor suspects a hereditary condition. Which of the following chromosomes is most likely involved in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The constellation of retinal hemangioblastoma and positive family history of possible renal malignancy is suggestive of von Hippel-Lindau disease.   

Von Hippel-Lindau disease is an inherited, autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by a variety of both benign and malignant tumors. The pathogenesis involves a mutation in the VHL tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3. The VHL gene normally encodes for a protein that functions as a part of the ubiquitin-ligase complex responsible for degrading the transcription factor hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF). Therefore, a mutation in the VHL gene mutation results in a high level of HIF that facilitates the expression VEGF, other growth factors, and occasionally erythropoietin, resulting in a stimulus for tumor growth.  

Patients with von Hippel-Lindau disease may present with hemangioblastomas throughout the central nervous system, bilateral clear cell renal cell carcinomas, and pheochromocytomas. Hemangioblastomas are benign, highly vascular tumors of the central nervous system. Symptoms occur due to compression of adjacent neural structures, bleeding, or paraneoplastic complications.  




Option Analysis

✅ Chromosome 3:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chromosome 5:
Incorrect: Mutations involving chromosome 5 are associated with Cri-du-chat syndrome and familial adenomatous polyposis. However, the presentation of retinal hemangioblastoma and positive family history of probable renal malignancy favors the diagnosis of von Hippel-Lindau disease.   
❌ Chromosome 7:
Incorrect: Mutations involving chromosome 7 are associated with Williams syndrome and cystic fibrosis. However, the presentation of retinal hemangioblastoma and positive family history of probable renal malignancy favors the diagnosis of von Hippel-Lindau disease.   
❌ Chromosome 9:
Incorrect: Mutations involving chromosome 9 are associated with Friedreich ataxia and tuberous sclerosis (TSC1). However, the presentation of retinal hemangioblastoma and positive family history of probable renal malignancy favors the diagnosis of von Hippel-Lindau disease.   
❌ Chromosome 22 :
Incorrect: Mutations involving chromosome 22 are associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 and DiGeorge syndrome (22q11). However, the presentation of retinal hemangioblastoma and positive family history of probable renal malignancy favors the diagnosis of von Hippel-Lindau disease.

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant is brought to the office because of difficulty feeding. The mother reports that whenever she tries to breastfeed the infant, he begins to sweat and grunt after a few minutes and stops feeding.  The patient was born via normal vaginal delivery at 38 weeks gestation to a 35-year-old mother. The infant’s mother did not receive prenatal care. Family history is unremarkable for hereditary disorders. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 30/min and blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg. Physical examination shows a single crease on both palms, a gap between the first two toes and prominent epicanthal folds. Auscultation reveals a fixed split S2 and grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border. Bibasilar crackles are present. Which of the following is the most likely to be found in association with this patient’s cardiac examination findings?
questions.solution:
This infant’s presentation with difficulty feeding and bibasilar crackles are consistent with heart failure, most likely due to atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD); auscultation correspondingly reveals a fixed split S2 and grade 2/6 ejection systolic murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border. The patient’s physical characteristics of a single palmar crease, gap between the first two toes and prominent epicanthal folds are suggestive of Down syndrome.  

Congenital heart defects affect around 40% of patients with Down syndrome, and AVSD is the most common defect in these patients. Other cardiovascular conditions associated with Down syndrome include mitral valve problems as patients age, tetralogy of Fallot, or patent ductus arteriosus.  

AVSD results from the failure of the endocardial cushions to merge, leading to a ventricular septal defect (VSD) and an atrial septal defect (ASD). In patients with AVSD, heart failure results from the mixing of blood between the chambers and the severe AV valve regurgitation, leading to volume overload and increased pulmonary blood flow.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Chromosome 22q11.2 deletion:
Incorrect: Chromosome 22q11.2 deletion results in DiGeorge syndrome. Cardiac manifestations in affected patients include transposition of the great arteries, which presents as neonatal cyanosis within 24 hours of birth and a single S2 on auscultation. Tetralogy of Fallot can also be seen in affected individuals, which presents with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo murmur with a single S2. A fixed split S2 and grade 2/6 ejection systolic murmur is indicative of atrioventricular septal defect.
❌ Complete loss of X chromosome:
Incorrect: A complete loss of X chromosome is indicative of Turner syndrome. Affected patients can have coarctation of the aorta (diminished peripheral pulses) or a bicuspid aortic valve. Moreover, physical examination usually reveals a short webbed neck and widely spaced nipples. A single palmar crease, gap between the first two toes, and prominent epicanthal folds would be atypical.
✅ Trisomy 21:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ CGG trinucleotide expansion:
Incorrect: CGG trinucleotide expansion results in fragile X syndrome. Affected individuals have large ears, long faces, and macroorchidism. Mitral valve prolapse is commonly seen in these patients, which presents with a mid-systolic click followed by a late-systolic murmur best heard at the apex. A single palmar crease, gap between the first two toes and prominent epicanthal folds are inconsistent with this diagnosis.
❌ Fibrillin-1 mutation:
Incorrect: Fibrillin-1 mutation is seen in patients with Marfan syndrome. Mitral valve prolapse and aortic dissection (rather than atrioventricular septal defect) are more prevalent in these patients. Affected individuals have tall stature and arachnodactyly.

questions.text: A 5-month-old girl is brought to the clinic for evaluation of abdominal distention. The mother states that although she feeds her frequently, she has “barely grown.” Her birth was unremarkable, and she can roll over on her own. Height and weight are below the 10th percentile. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 144/min, blood pressure is 86/62 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 48/min. Motor examination reveals hypotonia in all 4 limbs. Abdominal examination reveals ascites. The liver and spleen are enlarged and palpable. Liver biopsy shows hepatocytes that stain positive with Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS). Further analysis reveals an accumulation of abnormal structures of glycogen with fewer branch points and longer alpha-1-4-linked glucose polymers within hepatocytes. Which of the following biochemical processes is most impaired in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms of hypotonia, hepatosplenomegaly, and ascites, with further investigations revealing an accumulation of polyglucosan molecules (unbranched long chains of glucose) within hepatocytes. These findings are consistent with a diagnosis of the glycogen storage disorder (GSD) type IV, also known as Andersen disease, caused by a deficiency of 1,4-alpha-glucan branching enzymes.

Glycogen storage disorders are inherited errors in glycolysis/glycogenesis/glycogenolysis that results in accumulation of glycogen/metabolic end products. GSDs are classified into 5 main categories:

  •  Glycogen storage disease type I/Von Gierke disease results from a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase (converts glucose-6-phosphate to glucose), impairing the final step in glycogenolysis. Clinical manifestations include severe hypoglycemia and hepatic involvement. 
  •  Glycogen storage disease type II/Pompe disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase, an enzyme involved in the breakdown of glycogen within lysosomes. The inability to break down glycogen results in its accumulation in cardiac and skeletal muscle tissues, with prominent cardiac dysfunction. 
  •  Glycogen storage disease type III/Cori disease results from a deficiency in the debranching enzyme (alpha-1,6-glucosidase) involved in glycogenolysis. Absence of the enzyme results in the accumulation of dextrin (intermediates of glycogen) in hepatic and skeletal muscle tissue.  
  •  Glycogen storage disease type IV/Andersen disease leads to an accumulation of polyglucosan molecules (unbranched glucose molecules) in hepatic, cardiac, and skeletal muscle tissue due to a deficiency in the enzyme 1,4-alpha-glucan branching enzyme involved in glycogen synthesis. 
  • Glycogen storage disease type V/McArdle disease is caused by a deficiency of skeletal muscle glycogen phosphorylase, the rate-limiting enzyme in glycogenolysis, resulting in skeletal muscle myopathy, decreased exercise tolerance, and rhabdomyolysis.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Glycogenesis :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Glycogenolysis:
Incorrect: Accumulation of polyglucosan bodies in this patient’s hepatocytes indicates a diagnosis of Andersen disease, which is caused by a deficiency of the alpha-1,4-glucan branching enzyme, a protein involved in glycogenesis (glycogen synthesis), not glycogenolysis (glycogen breakdown). In contrast, hepatic involvement is seen with Von Gierke disease, which results from a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase, an enzyme involved in glycogenolysis. However, Von Gierke disease would not result in the accumulation of polyglucosan bodies within hepatocytes.
❌ Glycolysis:
Incorrect: Impairment in the steps of glycolysis does not result in hepatic involvement or the accumulation of polyglucosan bodies (unbranched long chains of glucose) in hepatocytes.
❌ Triglyceride synthesis:
Incorrect: Triglyceride synthesis is upregulated in glycogen storage disorders like Von Gierke disease and Cori disease. It is not affected in Andersen disease.
❌ Galactose metabolism:
Incorrect: Classic galactosemia (deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase) can cause hepatic involvement manifesting as failure to thrive, jaundice, hepatomegaly and cataracts. However, it does not cause accumulation of polyglucosan bodies (unbranched long chains of glucose) in hepatocytes.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man comes to the emergency department with painful muscle spasms. He reports that after starting a run, he experiences muscle cramps and fatigue, but these symptoms tend to improve after about 10 minutes of continued activity. His past medical history includes a right knee ACL tear. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Rapid fingerstick glucose is 80 mg/dL. Serum creatine kinase levels are elevated. Laboratory investigations are shown below:

 Serum 
 Sodium   140 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   1.3 mg/dL 
 Creatine kinase  645 U/L 
 Urine  
 BUN/Cr  <15 
 Blood   Positive  
 Erythrocytes  0/hpf 
 Leukocytes  2/hpf 
 Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa)   >2%  

Electrocardiogram and echocardiogram are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has presented with symptoms indicating skeletal myopathy progressing to rhabdomyolysis. The description of painful muscle spasms induced by exercise and subsequent improvement with continued activity (“second wind phenomenon”) is the classical description of musculoskeletal involvement in McArdle disease, also referred to as glycogen storage disease type V.

McArdle disease is an autosomal recessive condition caused by mutations in the gene coding for glycogen phosphorylase and typically presents in adolescence or early adulthood. McArdle disease is characterized by intracellular pathological accumulation of glycogen in muscle tissue due to a deficiency in skeletal muscle glycogen phosphorylase. Glycogen phosphorylase converts glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate, a rate limiting step in glycogenolysis. In the absence of this enzyme, glucose-1-phosphate cannot be released, and glycolysis is inhibited. Impairment of Na/K ATPase pumps leads to osmotic imbalances and myocyte cell death.

The subsequent damage to muscle cells results in the most commonly reported symptom: exercise intolerance. Other symptoms include painful muscle cramps, weakness, and fatigue. Muscle pain and stiffness occasionally can lead to painful contractures. Rhabdomyolysis is suspected when urine studies indicate blood in urine and an insignificant amount of erythrocytes, indicative of myoglobinuria. Complications such as intrinsic renal failure can occur, which is evidenced by acute kidney injury. A “second wind phenomenon” is an improvement in symptoms of muscular fatigue and stiffness after continued exercise. An important mechanism of the spontaneous second wind is related to increased blood flow, increased delivery of free fatty acids to the muscle, and increased fatty acid oxidation.

Genetic testing is the diagnostic test of choice. An invasive alternative method of investigation used in inconclusive cases is muscle biopsy, which will stain positive with Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain, indicating glycogen accumulations. 

Option Analysis

✅ McArdle disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Von Gierke disease:
Incorrect: Von Gierke disease is characterized by hepatomegaly, hyperuricemia, hypertriglyceridemia and lactic acidosis. It generally presents in infancy and does not cause severe muscle spasms, myopathy, or rhabdomyolysis.
❌ Pompe disease:
Incorrect: Pompe disease can cause skeletal myopathy due to accumulations of glycogen as a result of a deficiency of lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase. However, in most cases, cardiomyopathy manifesting as ventricular hypertrophy and arrhythmias are present.
❌ Cori disease:
Incorrect: Cori disease would present with generalized hypotonia, myopathy, and hepatomegaly with fasting hypoglycemia. This patient’s normal glucose levels and unremarkable abdominal examination makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Fabry disease:
Incorrect: Fabry disease can result in complications which include renal and cardiac failure. However, initial presenting symptoms include angiokeratomas, hypohidrosis and acroparesthesias, none of which are noted in this patient.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician to evaluate a suspected eating disorder. The child has been binge eating, and when his parents refuse to provide additional food, he becomes angry. He was hypotonic as an infant and had both feeding and growth problems due to a weak sucking reflex. He is at the 3rd percentile for height and 99th percentile for weight. Which of the following best describes the possible pathophysiology for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This child presents with hyperphagia, weight gain, and history of hypotonia and poor sucking in infancy; he likely has Prader-Willi syndrome, a rare genetic disorder caused by genomic imprinting.  

Typically, people inherit two genes, one from each parent, and both genes are active. However, occasionally only one of these genes is active, while the other copy is silenced. Which copy of the gene is active depends on parental origin. In some cases, specific genes are only active when inherited from the father, while others are only active when inherited from the mother. This phenomenon is known as genomic imprinting. The underlying mechanism of genomic imprinting involves DNA methylation, wherein adding a methyl group to the gene silences its expression.  

In some cases, the active gene is mutated or deleted, which can automatically result in disease because the other copy is silenced or “imprinted” (i.e. there’s no backup for that gene). For example, the genes involved in Prader-Willi syndrome, which are found on chromosome 15q (in a section known as the Prader-Willi critical region, or PWCR), require an active paternal copy – the maternal copy of the PWCR is always silenced. Therefore, if an individual inherits a mutation or deletion in the PWCR from their biological father, they will develop Prader-Willi syndrome. However, if their maternal copy of the PWCR is mutated or deleted, the individual will instead be strictly a carrier of the disease; this is because their maternal copy would have been silenced regardless.  

Another issue that can arise due to genetic imprinting is in cases of uniparental disomy, wherein a patient inherits two copies of a chromosome (or two copies of parts of the chromosome) from one parent and none from the other. This phenomenon becomes problematic for conditions such as Prader-Willi syndrome, in which maternal uniparental disomy results in the patient having zero paternal copies of the PWCR on chromosome 15q – in this case, both maternal copies will automatically be silenced, and the patient will manifest with Prader-Willi syndrome, just as if they had had a paternal mutation or deletion in the PWCR. Maternal uniparental disomy accounts for about 25% of cases of Prader-Willi syndrome, while 75% are simply the result of a mutated or deleted paternal copy of the PWCR.  

A similar phenomenon is seen in Angelman syndrome, although this condition instead requires an active maternal copy of the UBE3A gene (which is also found on chromosome 15), and the paternal copy is silenced. Therefore, in cases of paternal uniparental disomy, both paternal copies of UBE3A are automatically silenced, but the patient has no active maternal copies to express, and thus they will subsequently develop Angelman syndrome. The condition is characterized by intellectual disability, inappropriate laughter, and a persistently happy demeanor. Paternal uniparental disomy accounts for about 5% of cases of Angelman syndrome, while 95% are simply the result of a mutated or deleted maternal copy of UBE3A.  



Option Analysis

✅ Maternal uniparental disomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Paternal uniparental disomy:
Incorrect: Angelman syndrome can result from paternal uniparental disomy. This condition is characterized by intellectual disability, inappropriate laughter, and a persistently happy demeanor. This patient instead presents with findings characteristic of Prader-Willi syndrome, which can be caused by maternal uniparental disomy. 
❌ Autosomal trisomy:
Incorrect: Down syndrome is the most common autosomal trisomy, resulting from a trisomy of chromosome 21. These patients present with intellectual disability, hypotonia, and developmental delay. Hyperphagia is not a characteristic of early Down syndrome.
❌ Trinucleotide expansion:
Incorrect: Fragile X syndrome, myotonic dystrophy, and Huntington disease result from trinucleotide repeat expansions. This patient instead presents with findings characteristic of Prader-Willi syndrome, which can be caused by maternal uniparental disomy. 
❌ Mutation in FBN-1 gene:
Incorrect: Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder due to a mutation in FBN-1gene, resulting in the absence of fibrillin. These patients present with a marfanoid habitus (e.g., tall with long extremities, arachnodactyly), cystic medial degeneration of the aorta, and joint abnormalities. This patient instead presents with findings characteristic of Prader-Willi syndrome, which can be caused by maternal uniparental disomy.

questions.text: A 9-month-old male infant is brought to the physician by his parents to evaluate poor feeding and growth. The infant had had problems with feeding since birth and did not improve when he was switched to formula feeding. The mother states that his sucking reflex is weak. The infant had surgery for undescended testes three months ago. His vaccinations are up to date. He is in the 3rd percentile for both height and weight. On physical exam, the child exhibits hypotonia, almond-shaped eyes, a narrow face, and a triangular mouth. He is subsequently admitted and has a nasogastric tube placed for feeding. Genetic testing reveals a microdeletion on chromosome 15q. This child is at risk of developing which of the following clinical manifestations?
questions.solution:
This child presents with a weak sucking reflex, poor feeding, developmental delay, hypotonia, cryptorchidism, almond-shaped eyes, a narrow face, and a 15q deletion on genetic testing; this presentation is consistent with Prader-Willi syndrome. Prader-Willi syndrome is a complex genetic disorder that results from the absence of a paternal copy of the Prader-Willi critical region (or PWCR) on chromosome 15q.  

Typically, the maternal copy of the PWCR on chromosome 15q is silenced (also known as genomic imprinting), while the paternal copy of the gene is active. Most cases of Prader-Willi syndrome result from a paternal deletion of the PWCR on chromosome 15q; however, some cases arise from maternal uniparental disomy of chromosome 15q, where both copies of the PWCR are inherited from the mother. Because the maternal copy of the PWCR is imprinted, both maternal copies will be silenced, leading to the absence of any active PWCR genes.  

Neonates with Prader-Willi syndrome present characteristic facial features, including almond eyes, narrow face, and a triangular mouth, along with hypotonia and poor growth due to a weak sucking reflex. After the age of 1, children with Prader-Willi syndrome develop increased appetite and hyperphagia, leading to severe obesity. Other features of Prader-Willi syndrome include short stature, hypogonadism, cryptorchidism, poorly developed genitalia, incomplete pubertal growth, and infertility. Most children with Prader-Willi syndrome have mild to moderate intellectual disability and behavioral problems (e.g. temper outbursts). Diagnosis of Prader-Willi syndrome is accomplished via genetic testing, and treatment is directed towards preventing associated complications.  



Option Analysis

✅ Hyperphagia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Macroorchidism :
Incorrect: Patients with Fragile X syndrome develop macroorchidism during or after puberty. Genetic testing will reveal cytosine-guanine-guanine trinucleotide repeat expansion on the X chromosome. Physical examination features are typically subtle in infants but may reveal large ears, long faces, and flat feet.
❌ Wilms tumor:
Incorrect: Wilms tumor is the most common renal malignancy in children. Although most cases of Wilms tumor arise sporadically, the condition is associated with certain genetic disorders (e.g. WAGR syndrome). However, this patient most likely has Prader-Willi syndrome, which is not associated with an increased risk of Wilms tumor.
❌ Hearing loss:
Incorrect: Some genetic syndromes are associated with hearing loss, including neurofibromatosis type 2 and Alport syndrome. Hearing loss is not observed in patients with Prader-Willi syndrome.
❌ Cataracts:
Incorrect: Certain genetic disorders are associated with the development of cataracts, including myotonic dystrophy and galactosemia. Prader-Willi syndrome is not associated with the development of cataracts.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of difficulty swallowing. He says that for the past few months he has been having difficulty swallowing solid foods and feels like the food gets stuck in his neck. The patient is able to drink liquids without any problems. Additionally, the patient has noticed several new “bumps” that have appeared along the front and side of his neck. Over the past month, the patient has lost 10 lbs (4.5 kg) and feels progressively more fatigued. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows a tall, thin male with a decreased upper to lower body ratio and mild kyphoscoliosis. There are multiple > 1 cm in diameter rubbery lymph nodes along the right lateral neck as well as a 2 cm right upper thyroid nodule. Oral examination reveals the following:

Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient’s disease?

choices.text: Gain-of-function mutation in a tumor suppressor gene
Loss of function mutation in a tumor suppressor gene
Dominant negative mutation in the profibrillin gene

questions.solution:
This patient is exhibiting symptoms of advanced thyroid cancer (obstructive dysphagia to solids, with lymphadenopathy likely representing metastases) along with Marfanoid physical features (e.g., decreased upper to lower body ratio, mild kyphoscoliosis) and mucosal neuromas on oral examination. Together, these features suggest the diagnosis of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 2B.  

MEN type 2 is caused by a gain-of-function mutation in the RET gene, a proto-oncogene that promotes normal cell division. When it mutates, it becomes an oncogene that promotes constant cell division and causes cancer. Different RET mutations can cause either multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A or 2B. All three types of MEN (1, 2A, and 2B) are inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, though de novo cases can rarely occur.  



Like MEN type 2A, almost all patients with MEN type 2B will develop medullary thyroid cancer, and over half will develop a pheochromocytoma. The major difference is that MEN type 2B is NOT associated with parathyroid tumors, but it is instead associated with multiple mucosal neuromas, which are tumors that arise from nerve tissue. Aberrant nerve growth results in ganglioneuromatosis, usually in the mouth, but it can also happen in the intestine and cause bowel obstruction or chronic constipation.  

People with MEN type 2B tend to have a Marfanoid habitus, which means that their physical appearance is similar to those individuals with Marfan syndrome. This includes long limbs, sometimes with an arm span that exceeds the height of the individual, as well as long flexible fingers and a high arched palate.  

Option Analysis

❌ Gain-of-function mutation in a tumor suppressor gene:
Incorrect: A gain-of-function mutation leads to a gene product that has a new or different function than the normal variant. Gain-of-function mutations typically predispose to cancer when they encode oncogenes (genes with the potential to cause cancer), rather than tumor suppressor genes.  
❌ Loss of function mutation in a tumor suppressor gene:
Incorrect: A loss-of-function mutation leads to a gene product that either does not function at all or has less function than the normal variant. Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 1 is caused by a loss of function mutation in the MEN1 gene that produces a non-functional version of the tumor suppressor protein menin. MEN type 1 is not associated with medullary thyroid cancer.  
✅ Gain-of-function mutation in a proto-oncogene:
Correct: See Main Explanation below.  
❌ Loss-of-function mutation in a proto-oncogene:
Incorrect: A proto-oncogene is a normal gene that has the potential to cause cancer if mutated or overexpressed. Congenital aganglionic megacolon (Hirschsprung disease) is caused by a loss-of-function mutation in the RET proto-oncogene, whereas MEN type 2B is caused by a gain-of-function mutation in RET.  
❌ Dominant negative mutation in the profibrillin gene:
Incorrect: A dominant negative mutation leads to a dysfunctional gene product that also interferes with the ability of the normal allele to function. Marfan syndrome is caused by a dominant negative mutation in the FBN1 gene that produces fibrillin, leading to abnormal connective tissue; however, this condition is not associated with cancer.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is evaluated in the office for developmental delay. Over the past year, she has been receiving physical therapy for delays in gross motor skills. She was born to a 40-year-old woman who declined prenatal testing. The rest of the systemic review is unremarkable. Family history is noncontributory.  Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a round dysmorphic face with upslanting palpebral fissures, a furrowed tongue and abnormal palmar creases. Auscultation reveals a fixed S2 and a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the lower left sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with developmental delay and typical physical characteristics like a simian crease in the hands, a gap between the first two toes, incurved 5th finger, a flat facial profile, and epicanthal folds is suggestive of Down syndrome (DS).   
Down syndrome, or trisomy 21, is the most common autosomal trisomy and the most frequent form of intellectual disability caused by a chromosomal aberration. It is characterized by the presence of an extra copy of genetic material on chromosome 21, either in whole (trisomy 21) or in part (such as due to translocations).  

Nondisjunction of chromosome 21 during meiosis accounts for about 95% of the cases. Failure of chromosome 21 to divide during the first step of oogenesis results in one cell ending up with both chromosomes and the other with no chromosome. The final result is 2 cells with an extra chromosome, and two cells missing a chromosome. Alternatively, when nondisjunction occurs during the second step of oogenesis, the final result is one cell with an extra chromosome, one cell missing chromosome, and two with the right number of chromosomes. If a sperm cell combines with any of these that have a duplicate of chromosome 21, then the combined cell will have one extra copy of chromosome 21 (trisomy 21).  



Unbalanced robertsonian translocation accounts for about 4% of trisomy 21 cases, which occurs when the long arm of chromosome 21 translocates over to chromosome 14, forming two hybrids, one with both long arms and one with both short arms.  These individuals have 46 chromosomes; however, one chromosome consists of the long arms (the portion that contains the main genetic material) of both chromosomes 14 and 21. When this chromosome is duplicated for oogenesis, the resulting offspring can end up with three copies of the long arm of chromosome 21, thus presenting with a phenotype of trisomy 21.  



Option Analysis

❌ Trinucleotide repeat expansion:
Incorrect: A trinucleotide repeat expansion can result in a number of diseases, including fragile X syndrome, myotonic dystrophy and Huntington disease. Developmental delay with these characteristic facial features is indicative of trisomy 21.
✅ Meiotic nondisjunction:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Uniparental disomy:
Incorrect: In uniparental disomy, the offspring receives 2 copies of a chromosome from 1 parent and no copies from the other parent. Associated syndromes include Angelman syndrome and Prader Willi syndrome.
❌ Frameshift mutation:
Incorrect: Frameshift mutation results from selection or insertion of a number of nucleotides not divisible by 3, leading to a misreading of all nucleotides downstream. Duchenne muscular dystrophy can present with developmental delay, but the abnormal facies seen here (round dysmorphic face with upslanting palpebral fissures, a furrowed tongue, and abnormal palmar crease) would be atypical.
❌ Balanced translocation:
Incorrect: A balanced translocation is clinically silent and there is no excess or shortage of genetic material. The risk with balanced translocation (a carrier) occurs in future offspring, in whom there may be unbalanced translocations.

questions.text: A male newborn infant is evaluated in the nursery an hour after birth. He was born to a 39-year-old woman at 37 weeks gestation via a normal vaginal delivery. The patient’s mother did not receive any prenatal care and never took prenatal vitamins. Birth weight and length are at 5th percentile. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows small head and eyes, cleft palate, and multiple additional fingers on both hands. A small membranous sac with a loop of bowel protrudes from the patient’s midline. Cardiac auscultation reveals a harsh holosystolic murmur IV/VI in intensity over the left sternal border. The infant is transferred to the neonatal intensive care unit for further evaluation and management. Which of the following is the most likely chromosomal abnormality in this patient?
questions.solution:
This infant with typical physical characteristics of microcephaly and microphthalmia, cleft lip/palate, multiple fingers and omphalocele, in combination with a prominent holosystolic harsh murmur (indicative of a ventricular septal defect), likely has Patau syndrome (PS, trisomy 13).   

PS is a rare autosomal trisomy with an incidence between 1 in 10,000 and 1 in 21,700 live births. It is characterized by the presence of an extra copy of genetic material on chromosome 13, either in whole (trisomy 18) or in part (such as due to Robertsonian translocations). Nondisjunction of chromosome 13 during meiosis accounts for most of the cases, whereas unbalanced Robertsonian translocation accounts for a small number of trisomy 13 cases.  

The major risk factors for PS are advanced maternal age and family history. The overexpression of the genes on the extra chromosome 13 causes abnormal development of all types of cells. Affected patients can present with microcephaly, holoprosencephaly (failure of the forebrain to divide into the two hemispheres), meningomyelocele, and developmental delays, and they will likely develop severe intellectual disability. Problems in other organ systems include gastrointestinal (e.g. omphalocele), heart problems (e.g. septal defects) and renal problems (e.g. polycystic kidney disease).  


Dysmorphic features include cutis aplasia, which appear as scalp lesions with the absence of skin, microphthalmia, polydactyly, cleft lip/palate, and rocker bottom feet. More severe defects include cyclopia (a single eye at the center of the forehead), which can occur as a result of the holoprosencephaly. Most babies with PS die in utero, and if they do survive, they usually die shortly after birth, with a median survival time of three days; only about 5% of the babies with Patau syndrome survive past six months of life.  




Option Analysis

❌ 5p deletion:
Incorrect: Deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 (5p) results in Cri-du-chat syndrome. Affected patients present with microcephaly, hypertelorism, broad nasal bridge, moderate to severe intellectual disability, and high-pitched crying/meowing. A cleft lip/palate, multiple fingers, and omphalocele would be atypical.
❌ 22q11.2 deletion:
Incorrect:  Chromosome 22q11.2 deletion results in DiGeorge syndrome. Although its phenotypic features like cleft palate and micrognathia overlap with this patient, the additional findings like multiple fingers and omphalocele are inconsistent with the diagnosis. Moreover, the cardiac manifestations of affected patients with DiGeorge include tetralogy of Fallot or transposition of the great vessels, neither of which present with a holosystolic murmur.
✅ 47, XY, +13:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 47, XY, +21:
Incorrect: A 47, XY, +21 is characteristic of Down syndrome. Affected individuals present with flat face, oblique palpebral fissures and prominent epicanthal folds. A small head and eyes, cleft lip/palate, multiple fingers and omphalocele are atypical.
❌ 7q deletion:
Incorrect: Congenital microdeletion of long arm of chromosome 7 (7q) results in Williams syndrome. Affected patients have distinctive “elfin” facies with low nasal bridge, intellectual disability, hypercalcemia, well-developed verbal skills, extreme friendliness with strangers, and cardiovascular problems (e.g., supravalvular aortic stenosis and renal artery stenosis). A small head and eyes, cleft lip/palate, multiple fingers and omphalocele are inconsistent with the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the clinic due to a worsening productive cough. The patient states it has been getting worse over the past week, and she has noticed an increase in foul-smelling sputum with frequent bloody streaks in it. The patient has had multiple similar episodes in the past that improved with antibiotic treatment. The patient does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. She takes pancreatic enzyme supplements for chronic diarrhea. The patient’s temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 124/75 mmHg. Digital clubbing is present. Which of the following pulmonary function testing results are likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient, who has a history of recurrent pulmonary infections and chronic diarrhea, likely has cystic fibrosis (CF). Affected patients have thickened, viscous, and inspissated secretions at various mucosal surfaces, leading to lung destruction, gastrointestinal malfunction, and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency. The pulmonary changes are the most serious complications of CF, and although the disease causes systemic issues, progressive lung disease is the major cause of morbidity and mortality for most patients.  

The pulmonary changes seen in CF patients stem from obstruction of the air passages by viscous mucus, which predisposes patients to superimposed infections. Recurrent infections cause permanent dilation of bronchi and bronchioles due to destruction of smooth muscle and the supporting elastic tissue, resulting in bronchiectasis. Additionally, bronchiectasis is associated with raised concentrations of neutrophil elastase, which further damages peptides and proteins found in the extracellular matrix of airway cells.    

Bronchiectasis presents clinically as a persistent cough that produces copious amounts of purulent, foul-smelling sputum. Pulmonary function testing in patients would reveal findings consistent with obstructive pulmonary disease due to air trapping.

 



Option Analysis

✅   FEV1/FVC  Residual volume Total lung capacity Decreased  Increased  Increased :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   FEV1/FVC   Residual volume Total lung capacity Increased  Decreased  Decreased :
Incorrect: These pulmonary function testing findings are likely seen in restrictive lung diseases (e.g. pulmonary fibrosis). As the fibrosed lungs can no longer expand properly, all lung volumes decrease to certain extent. FEV1 decreases in this setting, but to a lesser extent than FVC, resulting in the FEV1/FVC ratio being increased. 
❌  FEV1/FVC  Residual volume Total lung capacity  NormalNormal Normal:
Incorrect: Normal pulmonary function testing is unlikely to be seen in this patient with an evident pulmonary disease. 
❌  FEV1/FVC  Residual volume Total lung capacity Decreased  Increased  Decreased:
Incorrect: Residual volume and total lung capacity are rarely discordant. Thus, these pulmonary function testing results are unlikely to represent a clinical disease.
❌  FEV1/FVC  Residual volume Total lung capacity Increased  Decreased  Increased :
Incorrect: Residual volume and total lung capacity are rarely discordant. Thus, these pulmonary function testing results are unlikely to represent a clinical disease.

questions.text: A 16-month old male infant is brought to the physician by his parents due to concerns about poor growth. The parents tell the physician that he seems to be growing slower than his sister when she was at the same age. At ten months, the patient began sitting unsupported but cannot walk at 16 months. His speech is incoherent. Vaccinations are up to date. Physical examination reveals a well-appearing child in no acute distress. Genetic testing shows increased copies of cytosine-guanine-guanine trinucleotides on the X chromosome. Which of the following clinical findings is expected to develop in this patient as he grows older?
questions.solution:
This male infant presents with developmental delay, and genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Fragile X syndrome (FGS).

Fragile X syndrome is an X-linked dominant genetic disorder due to cytosine-guanine-guanine (CGG) trinucleotide expansion in the 5’-untranslated region in the Fragile X mental retardation gene-1 (FMR-1) on the X chromosome. With the CGG expansion, cytosine nucleotides become methylated which subsequently silences the FMR-1 gene, thereby decreasing Fragile X Mental Retardation Protein (FMRP) production. This protein carries multiple neuronal functions and is critically important to normal neurological development.  

Patients with FGS are typically born without the characteristic phenotypic physical examination features. Neurodevelopmental abnormalities begin as the infant grows, and most patients present with delayed motor and verbal milestones. In addition, a significant number of patients with FGS develop behavioral abnormalities, including autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and attention-deficit-hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Most physical findings develop in the early pre-pubertal period and include a long face, flat feet, and large protruding ears. The hallmark physical finding in FGS patients is macroorchidism (enlarged testicles) which is not apparent until puberty.  

FGS is diagnosed via genetic PCR testing which measures the CGG repeats in the FMR-1 gene. Patients with FGS have >200 repeats, and those with CGG repeats between 55-200 have a pre-mutation. These carrier patients exhibit milder symptoms with fewer physical findings or evidence of mental disability. However, it is important to note that trinucleotide repeat expansion disorders such as FGS exhibit anticipation – meaning with subsequent generations, the number of repeats will increase, so the symptoms of FGS will grow more pronounced as the mutation is passed down through generations.  



Option Analysis

✅ Macroorchidism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute lymphoblastic leukemia:
Incorrect: Down syndrome is associated with an increased risk of developing acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). Patients with Down syndrome have dysmorphic features (e.g., upslanting palpebral fissure, low-set ears), and three copies of chromosome 21 are identified on genetic testing. This patient has Fragile X syndrome, which is not associated with an increased risk of developing ALL.
❌ Cataracts  :
Incorrect: Cataracts are observed in patients with myotonic dystrophy, an autosomal dominant disorder caused by expansion of cytosine-thymine-guanine (CTG) in the DMPK gene on chromosome 19. This patient has Fragile X syndrome, which is not associated with cataracts.
❌ Aortic root dilation:
Incorrect: Certain genetic disorders are associated with increased risk of aortic aneurysm and dissection, such as Marfan syndrome. However, patients with Fragile X syndrome (like this patient) do not carry an increased risk of aortic dissection.
❌ Gynecomastia  :
Incorrect: Patients with Klinefelter syndrome develop gynecomastia in puberty secondary to decreased testosterone production from fibrotic testicles. Klinefelter syndrome is a chromosomal aneuploidy, and genetic testing demonstrates a  47, XXY profile in a phenotypic male. This patient has Fragile X syndrome, which is not associated with gynecomastia.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with 2 days of productive cough and fever by her parents. The child was adopted at the age of 2, and the history of her biological family is unknown. The parents state the patient has had similar episodes in the past year, along with a history of chronic diarrhea. The patient’s temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 105/73 mmHg. Examination reveals tachypnea and use of accessory muscles. There are decreased breath sounds heard over the right lower lung. Chest x-ray reveals lower right lobar consolidation. Clubbing of the fingers is present. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This child is presenting with signs of cystic fibrosis (CF) (e.g., recurrent lung infections, chronic diarrhea, digital clubbing). CF has multisystem effects, and clinical features include recurrent pulmonary infections with worsening lung function and exocrine pancreatic dysfunction. The thick and inspissated mucous produced in the lungs predisposes patients to recurrent lung infections by various pathogens.

Lung infection with Staphylococcus aureus is a frequent problem in patients with CF, particularly during the first decade of life, resulting in recurrent pulmonary infections. Early lower airway infection with S. aureus in children with CF results in deteriorating lung function and increases the airway inflammatory response. This chronic inflammatory process in the lungs causes permanent dilation of bronchi and bronchioles, resulting in bronchiectasis. S. aureus colonization diminishes with age (although it is still an important cause of disease in adults with CF), while Pseudomonas aeruginosa becomes the most common cause of CF-related pneumonia in adults.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Staphylococcus aureus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
Incorrect: The prevalence of P. aeruginosa increases with age in cystic fibrosis (CF) patients, such that more than 60 percent of adults are chronically infected. With prolonged infection, P. aeruginosa converts to a mucoid phenotype, which allows for the formation of biofilms. In the first few decades of life, however, another pathogen more commonly causes pulmonary infections in patients with CF. 
❌ Burkholderia cepacia complex:
Incorrect: Chronic infection with Burkholderia cepacia complex bacteria is associated with an accelerated decline in pulmonary function and shortened survival in CF patients. It is not, however, the most common pathogen in children.
❌ Nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae:
Incorrect: Nontypeable H. influenzae is commonly found in the respiratory secretions of CF patients; however, it is not the most common pathogen to cause pulmonary infections in children.
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Incorrect: Although S. pneumoniae is the most common pathogen to cause community-acquired pneumonia, it is not likely to be the cause of infection in this child with cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to a seizure. His parents state that one hour ago while playing in the living room, the patient fell to the ground and started shaking his limbs uncontrollably. Prior history includes developmental delay, behavioral problems and multiple hospitalizations for generalized seizures. The patient was born through normal vaginal birth to a 25-year-old primigravida who had full prenatal care. There is no family history of genetic disorders. The patient’s temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min and blood pressure is 127/74 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is drowsy and postictal. A red demarcation is noted on the face, covering the forehead and upper eyelid. Further evaluation of this patient will most likely reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Low-grade astrocytic tumor along the optic pathway
Capillary-venous malformation within the subarachnoid layer
Perivascular epithelioid neoplasm within the kidney

questions.solution:
This child who presents with developmental delay, a facial port-wine stain, and a generalized seizure most likely has Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS). SWS is associated with leptomeningeal vascular malformations, which refers to capillary-venous malformations within the arachnoid and the pia mater (leptomeninges).  

SWS, also known as encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis, is a congenital nonhereditary vascular disorder characterized by facial capillary malformations (port-wine stain), leptomeningeal vascular malformation, seizures/epilepsy, intellectual disability, and various eye conditions (e.g., glaucoma, episcleral hemangioma).  

The pathogenesis includes somatic mosaic mutations in the GNAQ gene. Somatic mosaicism refers to the development of two genetically distinct cell populations within an individual due to a postzygotic mutation. Therefore, it is not a heritable disorder and recurrence is unlikely. The GNAQ gene encodes for a guanine nucleotide-binding protein called G-alpha-q. This protein functions to regulate intracellular signaling pathways. The mutation leads to an uncontrolled set of signaling pathways that are thought to be responsible for SWS.    





Option Analysis

❌ Low-grade astrocytic tumor along the optic pathway:
Incorrect: An optic glioma is a low-grade astrocytic tumor that occurs along the optic pathway. It is associated most commonly with neurofibromatosis type 1, but it is also seen in type 2. This patient most likely has Sturge-Weber syndrome, which is not associated with optic gliomas.   
✅ Capillary-venous malformation within the subarachnoid layer:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Cortical glioneuronal hamartomas:
Incorrect: A hamartoma is a growth of disorganized tissue indigenous to the tissue of origin. Both cortical glioneuronal hamartomas and subependymal nodules are considered hamartomas, which are part of tuberous sclerosis complex. Brain hamartomas are not part of Sturge-Weber syndrome.  
❌ Perivascular epithelioid neoplasm within the kidney:
Incorrect: A perivascular epithelioid neoplasm denotes an angiomyolipoma, which is associated with tuberous sclerosis complex rather than Sturge-Weber syndrome, as in this patient.   
❌ Long bone dysplasia:
Incorrect: Bone dysplasias refers to a group of disorders characterized by bone and cartilage growth abnormalities that affect bone development. These are typically associated with neurofibromatosis type 1, not Sturge-Weber syndrome.

questions.text: A scientist is researching the downstream effects of various mutations in the guanosine triphosphate hydrolase (GTP-ase) proteins family. She creates mutations in mice genes coding for these GTPase-activating proteins and follows their development. She concludes that mutations in those genes lead to unregulated Ras activity. If the same mutations occur in humans, which of the following manifestations will be expected?

choices.text: Recurrent pulmonary infections; malabsorption; pancreatic insufficiency
Brittle bones; conductive hearing loss; blue sclerae
Bilateral vestibular schwannomas; juvenile cataracts; ependymomas

questions.solution:
Neurofibromatosis type 1 is a neurocutaneous disorder that may be inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion or occur sporadically. Signs and symptoms include multiple café-au-lait spots (cutaneous patches of hyperpigmentation), intellectual disability, cutaneous neurofibromas, Lisch nodules, optic gliomas, pheochromocytomas, seizures, and skeletal disorders (e.g. scoliosis). Penetrance (the likelihood that the individual carrying the variant will manifest the disorder) is complete. However, NF1 is highly variable in its expression; the severity of and specific manifestations of the disorder vary among affected individuals within the same family.  

The pathogenesis involves mutations in the NF1 tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 17. Neurofibromin, the protein product encoded by this gene, belongs to a family of guanosine triphosphate hydrolase (GTPase)-activating proteins that facilitate intrinsic GTPase activity in the Ras protein family. Ras, in turn, is responsible for multiple pathways of cellular signal transduction. Since these proteins are expressed throughout the body, a defective neurofibromin leads to widespread Ras hyperactivity and the manifestation of NF1.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Lisch nodules; neurofibromas; scoliosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Recurrent pulmonary infections; malabsorption; pancreatic insufficiency:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with cystic fibrosis, an autosomal recessive condition caused by a defect in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7. It is most commonly caused by a deletion of Phe508, which results in a misfolded chloride channel that is subsequently degraded by intracellular proteasomes.  
❌ Brittle bones; conductive hearing loss; blue sclerae:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with osteogenesis imperfecta, an autosomal dominant bone disorder caused by a variety of gene defects (most commonly COL1A1 and COL1A2), resulting in decreased production of normal type I collagen.  
❌ Bronchiectasis; situs inversus; sperm immotility:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Kartagener syndrome (primary ciliary dyskinesia), an autosomal recessive condition due to mutations in the genes that code for the dynein arm of cilia. Kartagener syndrome is not associated with (GTPase)-activating protein mutations.  
❌ Bilateral vestibular schwannomas; juvenile cataracts; ependymomas:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with neurofibromatosis type 2, an autosomal dominant condition caused by a dominant loss of function mutation of the merlin gene located on chromosome 22. Merlin is a cytoskeletal protein that acts as a tumor suppressor by promoting E-cadherin-mediated contact inhibition. When merlin function is lost, cells can proliferate without inhibition.

questions.text: A 1-hour-old infant girl is brought to the nursery for evaluation. She was born via normal vaginal delivery at 38 weeks gestation to a 40-year-old woman. The infant’s mother did not receive prenatal care. Family history is unremarkable for hereditary disorders. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a single crease on both palms, a gap between the first two toes and prominent epicanthal folds. An abnormal harsh holosystolic murmur is heard at the lower left sternal border on auscultation of heart. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. This child is at increased risk of developing which of the following features in the future?

choices.text: Local bone pain and swelling of the long bones
Rapid, multi-directional eye movements and quick, involuntary muscle jerks
Unilateral abdominal mass, hypertension and hematuria
Renal mass, facial angiofibromas, ash leaf spots, and shagreen patches

questions.solution:
This infant's physical examination findings of a single crease on both palms, a gap between the first two toes and prominent epicanthal folds, in combination with cardiac auscultation revealing an abnormal harsh holosystolic murmur heard at the lower left sternal border, is highly suggestive of Down syndrome (DS).   

Down syndrome is the most common autosomal trisomy and the most frequent form of intellectual disability caused by a chromosomal aberration. It is characterized by the presence of an extra copy of genetic material on chromosome 21. Maternal age is a major risk factor. Typical features include intellectual disability, congenital abnormalities (e.g. duodenal atresia) and characteristic physical findings (e.g., simian crease, a gap between the first two toes and epicanthal folds).   

Patients with DS are at increased risk of leukemia, likely due to constitutive activity of the additional chromosome 21, which contains key enzymes involved in hematopoiesis. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is 20 times more common in patients with DS, whereas acute megakaryoblastic leukemia is 500 times more common in these patients. ALL typically presents in children as pallor, fever, bleeding/bruising, bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and recurrent infections. ALL in DS typically occurs in patients older than nine years and has a poor prognosis as compared to the normal population.  

Other hematologic manifestations associated with DS include transient myeloproliferative disease, which almost exclusively affects newborns with DS and resolves spontaneously within 3 months of birth.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Local bone pain and swelling of the long bones:
Incorrect: Osteosarcoma is characterized by symptoms of local bone pain and swelling of the long bones. The risk of osteosarcoma is increased in patients with inherited genetic mutations in retinoblastoma (RB1) tumor suppressor gene and TP53 (linked to Li-Fraumeni syndrome). This patient’s physical features are suggestive of Down syndrome, which predisposes her to another complication.
❌ Rapid, multi-directional eye movements and quick, involuntary muscle jerks:
Incorrect: These symptoms are indicative of opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome, which is characteristically found in association with neuroblastoma. It results from N-myc overexpression. Its risk is not increased in patients with Down syndrome (trisomy 21).
✅ Easy bruising and recurrent infections:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Unilateral abdominal mass, hypertension and hematuria:
Incorrect: This presentation is indicative of Wilms tumor, which results from a mutation in WT1 gene. The risk of developing Wilms tumor is increased in patients with Edward syndrome, not Down syndrome.
❌ Renal mass, facial angiofibromas, ash leaf spots, and shagreen patches:
Incorrect: Renal angiomyolipoma is a benign neoplasm found in association with tuberous sclerosis, a neurocutaneous disorder that results in multiple benign hamartomas of several organ systems. Affected individuals present with facial angiofibromas, ash leaf spots, and shagreen patches. Its risk is not increased in patients with Down syndrome.

questions.text: A 6-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician’s office for evaluation of an enlarged abdomen. Her parents state they have noticed a bulging, protuberant belly over the past several weeks. Her mother has also noticed she has been increasingly irritable in between her feedings, and she often wakes up crying at night and is only consoled with feedings. During her periods of irritability, the patient is often sweating, which resolves with feeding. She is exclusively breastfed. Her birth was unremarkable; however, she has not been able to sit up or crawl. Her weight is less than the 5th percentile for her age. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 122/min, blood pressure is 86/62 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 48/min. Physical examination reveals a lethargic infant. Facial examination reveals a rounded “doll's face-like” features with enlarged cheeks. Abdominal examination reveals massive and firm hepatomegaly. Genetic testing is performed, revealing a nonsense mutation in the gene encoding the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase. Which of the following laboratory findings can be expected in this patient, considering the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with an enlarging abdomen, signs of hypoglycemia between feeds (e.g., irritability, diaphoresis), and a mutation in the glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme, likely has Von Gierke disease, also known as glycogen storage disease type I.

Von Gierke disease classically presents between three to six months of age with symptoms of hypoglycemia which include irritability, fatigue, frequent nighttime awakening to feed and, in severe cases, seizures. Untreated patients may have developmental delays and short stature.

Von Gierke results from a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase, an enzyme involved in glycogenolysis that converts glucose-6-phosphate to glucose, due to a mutation in the G6PC gene. In the absence of glucose-6-phosphatase, G6P accumulates in the liver and kidney, manifesting as hepatomegaly and proteinuria. During periods of fasting (in between meals), although glucagon and epinephrine levels rise to stimulate glycogenolysis, the absence of glucose-6-phosphatase causes G6P to be shunted to alternate pathways. G6P is shunted down the glycolytic pathway, resulting in lactic acid production. Lactic acidosis can result in a wide anion gap metabolic acidosis.

G6P is also shunted towards ribulose-5-phosphate production via the HMP shunt pathway. Increased breakdown of adenine nucleotides as a result can cause hyperuricemia in these patients. Increased de novo lipid synthesis results in hypertriglyceridemia, increasing the risk of pancreatitis and xanthoma formation in untreated patients.

A histological analysis of a hepatic biopsy would reveal Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)-positive hepatocytes filled with glycogen. Diagnosis is confirmed by gene sequencing. Treatment of Von Gierke disease aims at maintaining glucose concentrations with frequent meals and administration of cornstarch, as its slow digestion provides a steady release of glucose.

Option Analysis

✅ Anion gap metabolic acidosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Normal lactate levels:
Incorrect: In the case of GSD type III and type V, not enough glucose is produced from glycogen, and as a result, lactate levels do not rise. In this patient presenting with GSD type I (Von Gierke disease), an inability to break down glycogen into glucose results in shunting of G6P down the glycolytic pathway, with resultant increased lactic acid production.
❌ Hyperglycemia:
Incorrect: Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency, the cause of Von Gierke disease, can result in severe fasting hypoglycemia due to an inability to convert glycogen to glucose despite a fasting state and elevated glucogenic hormones like glucagon and epinephrine.
❌ Respiratory acidosis:
Incorrect: Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency leads to shunting of G6P down the HMP shunt pathway. Increased degradation of adenine nucleotides results in lactic acidosis. Compensatory respiratory alkalosis, not respiratory acidosis, results from hyperventilation.
❌ Elevated creatine kinase:
Incorrect: Elevated creatine kinase is associated with Pompe disease (glycogen storage disease type II) due to skeletal myopathy. Pompe disease is caused by a deficiency of lysosomal acid alpha 1,4 glucosidase.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parent for a routine checkup. His parent describes him as very friendly, even with strangers. The patient’s growth was slow in the first year of life, where he was placed in the 3rd percentile for weight. His weight improved with a special formula, and he is currently at the 10th percentile for weight. The child was also discovered to have supravalvular aortic stenosis at two months. Physical examination demonstrates a child with a broad nasal bridge, wide forehead, and upturned nose. The child is extremely friendly with the physician. Labs demonstrate hypercalcemia. Which of the following is most likely the disease mechanism in this patient?
questions.solution:
This child presents with arteriopathy (supravalvular aortic stenosis), amicable demeanor, and an “elfin-like” appearance (e.g., broad forehead, wide nasal bridge, upturned nose). Together, these findings suggest a diagnosis of Williams syndrome.  

Williams syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the deletion of chromosome 7q11.23. This deletion involves 26-28 genes, including the elastin (ELN) gene. While most cases of Williams syndrome are due to sporadic deletions in the sperm or the ovum, a minority of cases are transmitted in an autosomal dominant fashion.  

As a result of the deletion of the elastin gene, patients tend to have short stature and supravalvular aortic stenosis at birth. Over time, other connective tissue disorders may arise, including peripheral pulmonary stenosis, joint hypermobility, and soft tissue laxity. Endocrinopathies are also common; patients with Williams syndrome have increased sensitivity to vitamin D, which leads to hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria early in life, predisposing them to kidney stones. Hypothyroidism may also be observed, in addition to precocious puberty. Patients with Williams syndrome typically have some degree of intellectual disability, ranging from mild to severe. These patients also tend to have unique personalities characterized by overfriendliness, distinctive empathy, anxiety, and phobias. Patients with Williams syndrome are usually diagnosed soon after birth due to the distinct “elfin-like” facies.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Chromosomal microdeletion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Meiotic nondisjunction:
Incorrect: Meiotic nondisjunction results in chromosomal aneuploidy (e.g., trisomy 21, trisomy 18). However, this child has features typical of Williams syndrome, which occurs due to a chromosomal microdeletion.
❌ Trinucleotide repeat expansion:
Incorrect: Trinucleotide repeat expansion is the underlying pathophysiology in several disorders, including Huntington disease, Fragile X syndrome, myotonic dystrophy, and Friedreich ataxia. However, this child has features typical of Williams syndrome, which occurs due to a chromosomal microdeletion.
❌ Genomic imprinting:
Incorrect: Genomic imprinting refers to the process of silencing an inherited copy of a gene from one parent while the gene from the other parent remains active. Mutations or deletions in the active gene can result in certain disorders (e.g., Prader-Willi syndrome, Angelman syndrome). 
❌ Uniparental disomy:
Incorrect: Uniparental disomy refers to an event in which both copies of a gene or chromosome are inherited from a single parent. If uniparental disomy of an imprinted gene occurs, a patient will be left without an active copy of the necessary gene. This phenomenon can occur in Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome. However, this child has features typical of Williams syndrome, which occurs due to a chromosomal microdeletion, not uniparental disomy.

questions.text: A 3-hour-old female neonate is being evaluated in the newborn nursery for hypotonia. The infant was born via vaginal delivery to a 25-year-old mother, who did not have a perinatal follow-up. Family history is non-contributory. The patient’s birth weight is below the 5th percentile, height at the 6th percentile, and head circumference at the 3rd percentile. On examination, the child appears hypotonic, and her cry is high-pitched and cat-like. In addition, she has a moon face, hypertelorism, a flat nose, and a prominent nasal bridge. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Deletion of the maternal copy of UBE3A gene

questions.solution:
This newborn female presents with hypotonia and dysmorphic features including a moon face, hypertelorism, and a flat nasal bridge. In addition, she has a high-pitched cat-like cry pathognomonic for Cri-du-chat syndrome.

Cri-du-chat syndrome is a genetic disorder that occurs due to a microdeletion in the short arm of chromosome 5 (5p). The manifestations and severity of Cri-du-chat syndrome are dependent on the size of the chromosomal deletion. Most cases of Cri-du-chat occur secondary to de novo deletions, while a minority are due to an unbalanced Robertsonian translocation.  

Hypotonia is usually seen in newborns with Cri-du-chat, and it may cause feeding difficulties and failure to thrive. However, the hypotonia may actually reverse, resulting in hypertonia later in life, causing gait abnormalities and clumsiness. In addition, characteristic facial features may develop later in life, including dental malocclusion and a dropped jaw. One of the distinctive features of Cri-du-chat is the monotonous, high-pitched, cat-like cry that results from laryngeal hypoplasia. Other findings include cardiac anomalies, intellectual disability, developmental delay, and behavioral issues (e.g., hyperactivity, temper tantrums).  

Diagnosis of Cri-du-chat occurs via karyotyping which will reveal a missing short arm on chromosome 5. In cases of high clinical suspicion with equivocal karyotyping, FISH (fluorescence in situ hybridization) can be used to confirm the deletion.  

There is no definitive treatment for Cri-du-chat, and the management aims to promote growth and socialization and prevent associated complications. Treatment thus involves behavioral modification therapy and special education.    



Option Analysis

✅ Microdeletion in chromosome 5p:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Trisomy of chromosome 21:
Incorrect: Although patients with Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) are often hypotonic, the facial features of this condition (e.g., upslanting palpebral fissures, low-set ears, single palmar crease) differ from this patient’s. Also, the aforementioned cat-like cry is pathognomonic for another condition.
❌ Monosomy of chromosome X :
Incorrect: Turner syndrome results from the monosomy chromosome X in females, causing a karyotype of (45, XO). Newborn females with Turner syndrome typically have evidence of a webbed neck, congenital lymphedema of the hands and the feet, nail dysplasia, and a narrow and high arched palate. This patient does not have characteristic features of Turner syndrome, and the aforementioned cat-like cry is pathognomonic for another condition.
❌ Deletion of the maternal copy of UBE3A gene:
Incorrect: Angleman syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that occurs due to the absence of a maternally inherited, active form of the UBE3A gene. Characteristic features include intellectual disability, developmental delay, seizures, and a distinctive happy demeanor with frequent smiling, hyperexcitability, and inappropriate laughter. This patient’s cat-like cry is pathognomonic for another condition.
❌ Deletion of chromosome 7q:
Incorrect: Williams syndrome occurs due to a deletion of chromosome 7q.
