NF1 is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder also known as von Recklinghausen disease. The pathogenesis involves mutations in the NF1 tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 17 that is responsible for control of cell division. This gene encodes for neurofibromin, a negative regulator of Ras.  

The "skin spots" described in this scenario are neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that consist of Schwann cells, fibroblasts, perineurial cells, and mast cells. Scoliosis, demonstrated by the forward bending test, is one of many skeletal phenomena that can be present in NF1 patients. The small papules present on the iris are Lisch nodules; they are hamartomas pathognomonic of NF1 that do not interfere with vision. Another common ophthalmologic manifestation of NF1 are optic gliomas, which are glial tumors of the optic pathway. Whereas Lisch nodules do not interfere with vision, optic gliomas can cause vision impairments. Additional signs of NF1 include café-au-lait spots (cutaneous patches of hyperpigmentation) and gliomas anywhere in the CNS. Patients with NF1 are also at increased risk of developing juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia, pheochromocytoma, and breast cancer in women.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Meningioma :
Incorrect: Meningiomas are tumors of arachnoid cell origin that commonly grow in the parasagittal region external to the brain parenchyma (extra-axial) and often have a dural attachment (“tail”). Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is an autosomal dominant syndrome associated with multiple tumors of the nervous system, including bilateral vestibular schwannomas (most commonly), meningiomas, and ependymomas. Other manifestations are neuropathies, cataracts, and subcutaneous nodules. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with NF type 1, which is not associated with meningiomas.   
❌ Retinal hemangioblastoma:
Incorrect: Hemangioblastomas are benign, highly vascular tumors of the central nervous system. They are associated with von Hippel-Lindau disease, an autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by retinal and cerebellar hemangioblastomas, renal cell carcinomas, pheochromocytomas, as well as other tumors.   
✅ Pheochromocytoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Renal angiomyolipoma:
Incorrect: Renal angiomyolipomas are benign tumors composed of vascular elements, smooth muscle, and adipose tissue. They often occur as one of the manifestations of tuberous sclerosis.  
❌ Renal cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common type of renal cancer and is characterized by the triad of flank pain, abdominal mass, and hematuria. Approximately 50% of patients with von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL) develop bilateral RCC.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is evaluated in the clinic for cognitive decline. The patient has a history of mild cognitive impairment, but he has been increasingly forgetful over the past few months. He previously enjoyed working at the community library but had to quit as he could no longer perform his duties. The patient is completely dependent on his caregiver for daily activities of living. He has recently been found lost on streets near his home on multiple occasions. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient is oriented to place and person only and is unable to cooperate with the remainder of the cognitive examination. Physical examination shows a single crease on palms, a gap between the first two toes and prominent epicanthal folds. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Extra copy of amyloid precursor protein
De novo mutation of MECP2 gene

questions.solution:
This patient with cognitive decline and typical physical findings of single crease on palms, a gap between the first two toes, and prominent epicanthal folds is most likely suffering from early onset Alzheimer dementia (onset at age ≤65 years) secondary to trisomy 21 (Down syndrome, DS).   

The amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene is located on chromosome 21; therefore, an extra copy of APP in DS is thought to accelerate the process of amyloid accumulation in the brain, leading to early onset AD. Other neurological conditions associated with trisomy 21 include:  

  •  Delayed developmental milestones (age of sitting (11 months), creeping (17 months), and walking (26 months)) and lower rate of language development.
  •  Mild to moderate intellectual disability with a decline in the IQ after age 10 years. 
  •  Disruptive behavior disorders (e.g., attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder, conduct/oppositional disorder, or aggressive behavior) is more common 
  •  Autism spectrum disorder is frequent in DS patients 
  • Increased risk of epileptic seizures, especially infantile spasms


Option Analysis

✅ Extra copy of amyloid precursor protein :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion:
Incorrect:  CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion results in fragile X syndrome. Although intellectual disability is common in these patients, affected individuals present with typical physical features like large ears, long faces, and macroorchidism. 
❌ De novo mutation of MECP2 gene:
Incorrect: De novo mutation of MECP2 gene is suggestive of Rett syndrome. Affected patients are usually female (since it is an X-linked dominant condition) and present within the first few years of life with regression in motor, verbal, and cognitive abilities, in addition to ataxia, seizures, growth failure, and stereotyped hand wringing. It is a highly unlikely cause of cognitive impairment in this older male patient.
❌ Silenced paternally derived UBE3A:
Incorrect: Silenced paternally derived UBE3A can result in Angelman syndrome, which manifests with seizures, ataxia, severe intellectual disability and inappropriate laughter. This patient’s physical exam features are instead suggestive of trisomy 21.
❌ Absence of hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyltransferase:
Incorrect: Absence of hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) results in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. Although intellectual disability is common in affected individuals, almost all patients present within the first few years of life. Additionally, patients typically have other symptoms including self-mutilation, aggression, hyperuricemia (orange “sand” [sodium urate crystals] in diaper), gout, and dystonia, all of which are absent in this patient.

questions.text: A 5-month-old girl is brought to the clinic due to difficulty feeding. Her parents have noticed she has been irritable and sweats excessively while feeding. Her birth was unremarkable; however, she has not been able to sit up or crawl yet. Her family immigrated from Nigeria 2 months ago. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 152/min, blood pressure 84/64 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 65/min. Her weight is less than the 5th percentile for her age. Motor examination reveals hypotonia in all 4 limbs. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Echocardiogram reveals biventricular hypertrophy. Laboratory investigations reveal markedly elevated creatine kinase levels. Fingerstick glucose is 70 mg/dL. Deficiency of which of the following enzymes is responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms of hypotonia, failure to thrive, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and laboratory investigations indicative of skeletal myopathy. This presentation is suggestive of Pompe disease, also referred to as glycogen storage disease type II.

Pompe disease results from a deficiency of lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase, which impairs glycogenolysis. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern and results from a mutation in chromosome 17. Deficiency of acid alpha-glucosidase is required for the lysis of alpha-1,6 and 1,4-glucosidase bonds in glycogen. As a result, glycogen accumulates in lysosomes, particularly those in the skeletal muscle and cardiac tissue, leading to dysfunction of the muscle cells.

 


Clinical manifestations are characterized by severe skeletal hypotonia and cardiomyopathy. The symptoms of heart failure in infants include irritability, difficulty feeding, tachypnea, diaphoresis while feeding, and failure to thrive. Prognosis for the infantile form is poor, and life expectancy is limited to 2 years of age; respiratory infections or dyspnea lead to respiratory failure, which is the most common cause of death in this disease.

Laboratory investigations that are supportive of a diagnosis of Pompe disease include elevated creatine kinase and elevated liver enzyme levels. A histological analysis of a skeletal muscle biopsy would reveal positive Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) staining, with vacuolated myocytes filled with glycogen.



By Jensflorian - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0,
Muscle biopsy showing large vacuoles in a case of Pompe disease (HE stain, frozen section).
Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

ECG and echocardiogram are reflective of cardiomyopathy with evidence of biventricular hypertrophy. Definitive diagnosis is made by genetic sequencing. In the United states, newborn screening that includes detection of Pompe disease among other glycogen storage disorders is recommended in many states. Early diagnosis and initiation of enzyme replacement therapy can improve morbidity and mortality. Complications include rhabdomyolysis, severe impairment in motor function, respiratory/cardiac failure, and developmental delays. 

Option Analysis

✅ Lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Glucocerebrosidase:
Incorrect: Fabry disease is a lysosomal storage disorder that is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme alpha-galactosidase. Accumulation of cellular byproducts can result in complications including cardiomyopathy and renal failure. However, the initial presenting symptoms include angiokeratomas, acroparesthesias (neuropathy of the extremities), and hypohidrosis. The absence of these symptoms makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Alpha-1,6-glucosidase:
Incorrect: Cori disease results from a deficiency of the debranching enzyme (alpha-1,6-glucosidase) and results in the accumulation of limit dextrin-like structures in the cytosol. Most patients have hepatomegaly, skeletal muscle involvement, and hypoglycemia.
❌ Glucose-6-phosphatase:
Incorrect: Von Gierke disease is caused by a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase. It does present in infancy with hypotonia; however, it is characterized by severe fasting hypoglycemia.  An elevated creatine kinase level and cardiomyopathy are suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Skeletal muscle glycogen phosphorylase:
Incorrect: McArdle disease results in the accumulation of glycogen in muscle due to a deficiency of skeletal muscle glycogen phosphorylase. It generally presents in early childhood or adolescence and is associated with painful muscle spasms, particularly after exercise, and elevated creatine kinase. However, cardiac muscle involvement is not common.

questions.text: A scientist is researching the effect of a new drug, Drug X, on protein processing in cells with a mutation in a particular gene encoding a transmembrane ion channel. The scientist notices that the mutated gene creates an unstable and misfolded protein that accumulates in the endoplasmic reticulum. The mutated protein is eventually transported to the cytosol, where it is ubiquitinated and degraded by proteasomes. Addition of Drug X improves the conformational stability of the protein, resulting in increased processing and trafficking of mature protein to the cell surface. Drug X is most similar to which of the following medications?
questions.solution:
Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic condition caused by mutations in the gene encoding the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), an anion channel in the apical membrane of epithelial cells that allows secretion of chloride. There are more than 1500 disease-causing mutations that can occur in the CFTR gene, with some presenting as more severe symptoms than others. The most common severe CFTR mutation is a deletion of three nucleotide bases coding for phenylalanine at amino acid position 508 (ΔF508). This mutation causes the protein to become unstable, resulting in accumulation of misfolded proteins in the endoplasmic reticulum, with eventual degradation by proteasomes.  

Lumacaftor is a novel drug in the treatment of CF (specifically in patients with the ΔF508 mutation) that improves the processing and conformational stability of the mutated CFTR protein, hence enabling more of the protein to be successfully transported to the cell surface. It is often used in conjunction with ivacaftor, which binds directly and selectively to the CFTR channel that is now able to reach the cell surface. Ivacaftor potentiates the CFTR channel by increasing its open probability and its transport of chloride. This drug combination has been found to improve lung function in CF patients and also reduce the number of pulmonary exacerbations.  



Option Analysis

✅ Lumacaftor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ivacaftor:
Incorrect: Although used in conjunction with lumacaftor in the treatment of CF, ivacaftor has a different mechanism of action; it binds directly to the CFTR channel and increases the channel’s open probability and transport of chloride. 
❌ Palivizumab :
Incorrect: Palivizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), which is used to help prevent serious RSV infection in young children who are at high risk, such as those with CF. 
❌ Prednisone:
Incorrect: Prednisone is a glucocorticoid that is occasionally used in patients with CF to reduce airway inflammation. It does not, however, affect protein stability and trafficking within the cell. 
❌ N-acetylcysteine:
Incorrect: N-acetlycysteine cleaves disulfide bonds within mucus glycoproteins and can liquefy CF sputum, improving mucociliary clearance. It does not, however, affect protein stability and trafficking within the cell.

questions.text: A female newborn infant is evaluated in the nursery 2 hours after birth. She was born to a 35-year-old woman at 37 weeks gestation via a normal vaginal delivery. The patient’s mother did not receive any prenatal care and never took prenatal vitamins. Birth weight and length are at 5th percentile. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an infant with low set ears, prominent occiput, micrognathia, and flexed fingers, with the index finger overlapping the third finger, and the fifth finger overlapping the fourth. Cardiac auscultation reveals a harsh holosystolic murmur IV/VI in intensity, over the left sternal border. The infant is transferred to the neonatal intensive care unit for further evaluation and management. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Partial deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5

questions.solution:
This infant with typical physical characteristics of low set ears, prominent occiput, micrognathia, and flexed fingers, with the index finger overlapping the third finger, and the fifth finger overlapping the fourth, in combination with growth restriction (birth weight and length at 5th percentile) and a prominent holosystolic harsh murmur (indicative of a ventricular septal defect), most likely has Edward syndrome (ES, trisomy 18).   

ES is the second most common autosomal trisomy (after Down syndrome) with an incidence of 1 in 5,000 live births. It is characterized by the presence of an extra copy of genetic material on chromosome 18, either in whole (trisomy 18) or in part (such as due to Robertsonian translocations). Nondisjunction of chromosome 18 during meiosis accounts for most of the cases, whereas unbalanced robertsonian translocation accounts for a small number of trisomy 18 cases. The major risk factors for ES are advancing maternal age and family history. It is also 3 times more common in females.  

The overexpression of the genes on the extra chromosome 18 causes abnormal development of all types of cells. Affected infants have severe intellectual disability, failure to thrive, congenital heart defects (e.g., septal defects and patent ductus arteriosus), omphalocele and esophageal atresia (which can lead to polyhydramnios during the pregnancy). Other complications include horseshoe kidneys, pulmonary hypoplasia, and frequent infections. These individuals are also at increased risk of developing Wilms tumor and hepatoblastoma.  

Dysmorphic features include microcephaly, a prominent occiput, low-set ears, cleft lip and palate, micrognathia, clenched hands with overlapping fingers, and rocker-bottom feet. Most babies with ES die before birth, whereas, those that survive labor and delivery usually die within a few weeks to months after birth.  



Option Analysis

❌ Loss of paternal X chromosome:
Incorrect: A complete loss of X chromosome is indicative of Turner syndrome. Physical examination usually reveals a short webbed neck (due to cervical lymphatic system obstruction and distension), widely spaced nipples, and bilateral extremity swelling. Affected patients can have coarctation of aorta (diminished peripheral pulses) and/or a bicuspid aortic valve. In contrast, this patient’s low set ears, prominent occiput, micrognathia, and flexed and overlapping fingers would be atypical for a patient with Turner syndrome.
❌ Partial deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5:
Incorrect: Partial deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 results in Cri-du-chat syndrome.  Affected patients present with microcephaly, hypertelorism, broad nasal bridge, moderate to severe intellectual disability, and high-pitched crying/meowing. This patient with low set ears, prominent occiput, micrognathia, and flexed and overlapping fingers is most likely suffering from Edward syndrome.
❌ CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion:
Incorrect:  A CGG trinucleotide expansion results in fragile X syndrome. Affected individuals are almost always male and have large ears, long faces and macroorchidism. Mitral valve prolapse (which usually presents with mid-systolic click, followed by a late systolic murmur) is commonly seen in these patients. This patient with low set ears, prominent occiput, micrognathia, and flexed and overlapping fingers is most likely suffering from Edward syndrome.
❌ Robertsonian translocation involving fetal chromosome 21:
Incorrect: Robertsonian translocation involving fetal chromosome 21 results in Down syndrome. Affected individuals present with flat face, oblique palpebral fissures, and prominent epicanthal folds. Flexed and overlapping fingers, a prominent occiput, and micrognathia as seen in this patient would be atypical for Down syndrome patients.
✅ Meiotic nondisjunction of fetal chromosome 18:
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother for numerous bruises on his body. The patient has a history of multiple hospital admissions since birth for recurrent respiratory infections. The patient’s mother states that she has noticed greasy, foul-smelling stool in the toilet bowl after her son goes to the bathroom. The patient’s vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals scattered ecchymoses across the body. Laboratory results are as follows:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Bleeding time  Normal 
 Prothrombin time   Elevated 
 Activated partial thromboplastin time  Elevated 

Which of the following is the most likely pathogenesis for this patient’s abnormal bleeding?

choices.text: Deficiency of endothelial-released factor that mediates platelet adhesion

questions.solution:
This patient, presenting with multiple bruises over his body, as well as a history of pulmonary infections and malabsorptive diarrhea, likely has cystic fibrosis (CF). CF is a hereditary condition that causes defective chloride channels in the cell membranes of exocrine glands, such as in the pancreas. Epithelial cells in the pancreatic ducts become plugged by thick mucus, which results in a chronic obstructive pancreatitis. This resultant exocrine pancreatic insufficiency is characterized by malabsorption and greasy, bulky, foul-smelling stools. The faulty fat absorption can result in a deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins (vitamins A, D, E, K).

This boy’s history of bruising is consistent with the signs of vitamin K deficiency. Vitamin K is an essential cofactor for γ-carboxylation of glutamic acid residues in specific coagulation factors, such as factors II (prothrombin), VII, IX, X, as well as proteins C and S. Since factors from both the intrinsic and extrinsic coagulation pathways are deficient, there is an increase in prothrombin and partial thromboplastin time. Since platelet synthesis and function is unaffected, bleeding time is normal. Patients are typically treated with pancreatic enzyme supplementation, as well as oral supplementation of the lipophilic vitamins.  



Option Analysis

❌ Hereditary deficiency of coagulation factor:
Incorrect: Hemophilia A is a hereditary cause of abnormal bleeding; it is caused by an X-linked defect that results in impaired production of factor VIII. Patients typically present with repeated hemarthrosis (bleeding into a joint), and laboratory testing would show prolonged PTT with normal bleeding time and PT. 
❌ Deficiency of endothelial-released factor that mediates platelet adhesion:
Incorrect: von Willebrand factor (vWF) is produced by endothelial cells. It functions as a mediator of platelet adhesion and aggregation and is a carrier protein for factor VIII. Therefore, patients with vWF deficiency present with elevated bleeding time and prolonged PTT, but PT is typically normal. 
✅ Impaired γ-carboxylation of coagulation factors :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Consumptive coagulopathy:
Incorrect: Disseminated intravascular coagulopathy (DIC) is a consumptive coagulopathy that occurs secondary to a systemic inflammatory response (e.g. septic shock). PT, PTT, and bleeding time are all prolonged. 
❌ IgG antibodies against platelet receptors :
Incorrect: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) can be seen in children following a viral infection. The responding immune system produces IgG antibodies against receptors found on platelets that results in splenic removal of platelets. Patients can present with bruising and petechiae, and coagulation tests would show elevated bleeding time only.

questions.text: A 12-month-old girl is brought to the ED by her mother due to vomiting and lethargy for the past 24 hours. The patient is formula-fed and has had normal feeding patterns until several hours ago, when she had an episode of vomiting. The mother reports they were at a barbecue outside yesterday for several hours, but that the baby had proper coverage from the sun. The patient has a history of meconium ileus after birth, when she was subsequently tested and found to have a homozygous ΔF508 deletion in the CFTR gene. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 134/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 98/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a stuporous girl with dry mucous membranes. Which of the following laboratory results are likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has cystic fibrosis, as indicated by the genetic testing at birth that revealed a homozygous ΔF508 deletion in the CFTR gene. The CFTR gene encodes a transmembrane chloride channel that regulates ion transport in the epithelial cells of various organs (e.g., sweat glands, lungs, pancreas).  

When eccrine sweat is initially produced, it is isotonic with extracellular fluid. As the sweat travels through the duct to the skin surface, chloride is normally reabsorbed by the CFTR channel, with sodium and water following. However, patients with CF have a dysfunctional CFTR channel that is unable to reabsorb chloride and sodium, and therefore, these patients secrete sweat with high chloride and sodium levels.    

The exposure of this infant with CF to high temperatures resulted in profuse sweating with hyponatremic and hypochloremic dehydration. This loss of water and electrolytes activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), which causes potassium and hydrogen excretion, as well as bicarbonate reabsorption (hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis). To avoid these life-threatening episodes, routine supplementation with sodium chloride is recommended.  

 

Option Analysis

✅   Sodium  Potassium  Bicarbonate  ↓  ↓  ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Sodium  Potassium  Bicarbonate ↑  ↓  ↑ :
Incorrect: While most cases of dehydration result in a hypernatremic state (due to loss of water), this patient with cystic fibrosis has improper regulation of sweat production, resulting in an excessive loss of sodium.
❌   Sodium  Potassium  Bicarbonate  ↓  ↑ ↑ :
Incorrect: This patient with severe dehydration would be expected to have upregulation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. The increased aldosterone would be expected to cause a decrease in serum potassium, not increase. 
❌   Sodium  Potassium  Bicarbonate  ↓  ↓  ↓:
Incorrect: This patient with severe dehydration would be expected to have upregulation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, which would cause an increase in renal bicarbonate reabsorption, not decrease. 
❌   Sodium  Potassium  Bicarbonate  ↑ ↓   ↓ :
Incorrect: Most cases of dehydration result in a hypernatremic state (due to loss of water). However, this patient has cystic fibrosis, which causes improper regulation of sweat production. Patients with cystic fibrosis will have excess sodium loss via sweat and present with hyponatremia. Furthermore, this patient with severe dehydration would be expected to have upregulation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, resulting in elevated bicarbonate.

questions.text: A 6-year-old adopted boy is brought to the physician to discuss his genetic testing results. The child had been having difficulties communicating with others in the classroom and was subsequently diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder and an intellectual disability. The genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Fragile X syndrome. Which of the following family pedigrees represents this patient’s biological family history? (Arrows indicating the patient).
questions.solution:
This adopted child is found to have Fragile X syndrome, which is an X-linked dominant disorder that results from the trinucleotide repeat expansion of cytosine-guanine-guanine (CGG) on the X chromosome, which silences the Fragile X Mental Retardation 1 gene (FMR1).  

X-linked dominant disorders refer to genetic mutations on the X-chromosome where only one copy of the mutated gene in the cell is sufficient to cause disease. Transmission of X-linked dominant disorders depends on which of the parents carry the mutated gene. If the father is affected (i.e. his only X chromosome has the mutation), then all of his female children will be affected by the disease. However, because the father gives away the Y chromosome for his male children, X-linked disorders cannot be transmitted from the father to his male children.  

On the other hand, if the mother has an X-linked dominant disorder, there is a 50% chance that the mutated X chromosome will be transmitted to her offspring and a 50% chance of transmitting the normal copy of the X chromosome. Therefore, all of her children (males and females) have a 50% chance of having the disease.   

In addition, it is important to note that trinucleotide repeat expansion disorders such as FGS exhibit anticipation – meaning with subsequent generations, the number of repeats will increase, so the symptoms of FGS will grow more pronounced as the mutation is passed down through generations.  



Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: This family pedigree represents an X-linked recessive disorder, given that the males in the tree express the disease, and females are carriers. Fragile X syndrome is X-linked dominant.  
❌ :
Incorrect: In this pedigree, each female transmits the mutation to all of her children (males and females), while males do not transmit the disease to their offspring. This pattern occurs in mitochondrial disorders. Fragile X syndrome is instead inherited with an X-linked dominant pattern.  
❌ :
Incorrect: In this pedigree, males and females express the disease equally, and it does not skip generations–reflective of an autosomal dominant pattern. Fragile X Syndrome is an X-linked dominant disorder, and males cannot transmit the disease to their male offspring (i.e. no male-to-male transmission).  
❌ :
Incorrect: This pattern reveals skipping of generations, and the condition affects both males and females almost equally. This pattern is characteristic of autosomal recessive disorders. Fragile X syndrome is instead inherited with an X-linked dominant pattern.
